elements.content: Three new dynamic metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) namely {[Cd2(3,4-pyrdc)2(4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)2]·4H2O} n (1), {[Mn2(3,4-pyrdc)2(bpee)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (2), and {[Cu2(3,4- pyrdc)2(bpp)2(H2O)4]·5H2O} n (3), based on 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylate (3,4-pyrdc) and three different N,N′-donor ligands [4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy), 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee), and 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)-propane (bpp)] with various divalent transition metal ions have been synthesized and characterized by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction and other physicochemical methods. In compounds 1 and 2, the 3,4-pyrdc ligand forms two-dimensional (2D) metal–carboxylate sheets that are connected by N,N′-donor ligands to form three-dimensional (3D) structures with water-filled channels. In compound 3, the 3,4-pyrdc ligand affords one-dimensional metal–carboxylate chains. These chains are connected by the more flexible bpp ligand to form 2D structures, which are extended to a 3D supramolecular architecture by H-bonding. Compounds 1 and 2 show a reversible crystalline-to-crystalline phase transformation upon dehydration and rehydration, whereas compound 3 exhibits an interesting reversible crystalline-to-amorphous transformation. These transformations have been established and monitored by exhaustive X-ray powder diffraction, elemental analysis, IR spectroscopy, thermogravimetric analysis, and morphology studies. The dehydrated forms of 1–3 selectively adsorb CO2 over N2 and also exhibit stepwise water uptake.

In compounds 1 and 2, the 3,4-pyrdc ligand forms two-dimensional (2D) metal-carboxylate sheets that are connected by N,N'-donor ligands to form three-dimensional (3D) structures with water-filled channels. The dehydrated forms of 1-3 selectively adsorb CO2 over N2 and also exhibit stepwise water uptake.

elements.content: Three dynamic MOFs showing reversible crystalline-to-crystalline and crystalline-to-amorphous phase transformations upon dehydration/rehydration have been synthesized. All of the dehydrated species selectively adsorb CO2 over N2 and also exhibit stepwise water adsorption.

elements.content: Materials with impressive flexibility that can undergo chemical and physical changes in the presence of several external stimuli (e.g., heat, light, pressure, etc.) have recently taken the limelight of interest because of their potential applications in the design of different molecular devices such as sensors, data storage devices, and switches. In this context, such flexibility in the structure of a molecule has emerged as a new contrivance for the development of next-generation functional materials. Thus, in a natural way, the dynamic porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) have also attracted significant attention in terms of functionality, as their structural flexibility allows them to alter their host structures in response to the aforesaid external stimuli. Because of this dynamic behavior, flexible MOFs have been found to exhibit unique selective, stepwise adsorption, which might be useful for the separation of gases and solvent vapors along with sensing of small molecules. It has been already established that flexible or dynamic MOF-based materials can be constructed by judicious choice of metal nodes and comparatively nonrigid organic linkers or by utilizing the interplay of weak non-covalent forces (hydrogen bonding, π–π stacking, and/or other supramolecular interactions). It is most often the case that the structural transformations in such MOFs are associated with the removal or exchange of guest molecules, changes in coordination number of metal atoms, bond rearrangement, and conformational changes in flexible organic linkers. Recently, reversible single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations or crystalline-to-microcrystalline transformations triggered by various external stimuli have been reported in some MOFs. There are also some rare instances where it has been observed that although the long-range crystallinity of MOFs may break down upon desolvation, leading to the formation of amorphous phases, the original crystallinity can be restored upon desolvation, i.e., reversible crystalline-to-amorphous transformation. However, from an implicational point of view, the crystalline-to-amorphous transformation is much more appealing because it might be associated with the radical changes in crystal-structure-dependent physical properties such as color and second-order nonlinear optical (NLO), magnetic, and ferroelectric properties. However, the exact reason for such structural flexibility and specific structural information accounting for the phase transition still exist as a gray area of science, and also, the specific functional applications of these frameworks have yet to be explored.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Materials with impressive flexibility that can undergo chemical and physical changes in the presence of several external stimuli (e.g., heat, light, pressure, etc.) have recently taken the limelight of interest because of their potential applications in the design of different molecular devices such as sensors, data storage devices, and switches. In this context, such flexibility in the structure of a molecule has emerged as a new contrivance for the development of next-generation functional materials. Thus, in a natural way, the dynamic porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) have also attracted significant attention in terms of functionality, as their structural flexibility allows them to alter their host structures in response to the aforesaid external stimuli. Because of this dynamic behavior, flexible MOFs have been found to exhibit unique selective, stepwise adsorption, which might be useful for the separation of gases and solvent vapors along with sensing of small molecules. It has been already established that flexible or dynamic MOF-based materials can be constructed by judicious choice of metal nodes and comparatively nonrigid organic linkers or by utilizing the interplay of weak non-covalent forces (hydrogen bonding, π-π stacking, and/or other supramolecular interactions). It is most often the case that the structural transformations in such MOFs are associated with the removal or exchange of guest molecules, changes in coordination number of metal atoms, bond rearrangement, and conformational changes in flexible organic linkers. Recently, reversible single-crystal-to-single-crystal transformations or crystalline-to-microcrystalline transformations triggered by various external stimuli have been reported in some MOFs. There are also some rare instances where it has been observed that although the long-range crystallinity of MOFs may break down upon desolvation, leading to the formation of amorphous phases, the original crystallinity can be restored upon desolvation, i.e., reversible crystalline-to-amorphous transformation. However, from an implicational point of view, the crystalline-to-amorphous transformation is much more appealing because it might be associated with the radical changes in crystal-structure-dependent physical properties such as color and second-order nonlinear optical (NLO), magnetic, and ferroelectric properties. However, the exact reason for such structural flexibility and specific structural information accounting for the phase transition still exist as a gray area of science, and also, the specific functional applications of these frameworks have yet to be explored.

elements.content: Recent studies have revealed that a mixed-ligand strategy for designing MOFs are found very effective for the incorporation of flexibility within the framework structure. Hence, utilizing the mixed-ligand approach, here we have synthesized three new dynamic MOFs, {[Cd2(3,4-pyrdc)2(4,4′-bipy)­(H2O)2]·4H2O} n (1), {[Mn2(3,4-pyrdc)2(bpee)­(H2O)2]·H2O} n (2), and {[Cu2(3,4-pyrdc)2(bpp)2(H2O)4]·5H2O} n (3), using 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylate (3,4-pyrdc) with different metal ions and three different N,N′-donor ligands [4,4′-bipyridine (4,4′-bipy), 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene (bpee), and 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane (bpp)]. The compounds have been characterized by single-crystal and powder X-ray diffraction as well as other physicochemical methods. Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit a reversible crystalline-to-crystalline phase transformation upon dehydration and rehydration, whereas compound 3 shows a rare reversible crystal-to-amorphous phase transformation accompanying a visible color change with respect to removal and addition of guest molecules () All three compounds after the phase transformation exhibit nice selective adsorption of CO2 gas over N2 and stepwise water adsorption, indicating the flexible nature of frameworks.

elements.content: Highly pure Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O, MnCl2·4H2O, Cu­(NO3)2·3H2O, 4,4′-bipyridine, 1,2-bis­(4-pyridyl)­ethylene, 1,3-bis­(4-pyridyl)­propane, and 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2-3,4-pyrdc) were purchased from the Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. All of the other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials

Highly pure Cd(NO3)2⋅4H2O, MnCl2⋅4H2O, Cu(NO3)2⋅3H2O, 4,4'-bipyridine, 1,2-bis(4-pyridyl)ethylene, 1,3-bis(4-pyridyl)propane, and 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid (H2-3,4-pyrdc) were purchased from the Sigma-Aldrich Chemical Co. All of the other reagents and solvents were purchased from commercial sources and were used without further purification.

elements.content: Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Heraeus CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra (4000–400 cm–1) were taken on KBr pellets using PerkinElmer Spectrum BX-II IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a METTLER TOLEDO TGA 850 thermal analyzer under a nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate = 30 cm3 min–1) over a temperature range of 30–600 °C at a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns in different states of the compounds were recorded on a Bruker D8 Discover instrument using Cu Kα radiation. The morphologies of the compounds in thin films were studied by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) using an FEI Inspect F50 microscope.
elements.clean_text:
Physical Measurements

Elemental analyses (carbon, hydrogen, and nitrogen) were performed using a Heraeus CHNS analyzer. Infrared spectra (4000-400 cm-1) were taken on KBr pellets using PerkinElmer Spectrum BX-II IR spectrometer. Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA) was carried out on a METTLER TOLEDO TGA 850 thermal analyzer under a nitrogen atmosphere (flow rate = 30 cm3 min-1) over a temperature range of 30-600 °C at a heating rate of 2 °C/min. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) patterns in different states of the compounds were recorded on a Bruker D8 Discover instrument using Cu Kα radiation. The morphologies of the compounds in thin films were studied by field-emission scanning electron microscopy (FESEM) using an FEI Inspect F50 microscope.

elements.content: H2-3,4-pyrdc (1 mmol, 168 mg) was deprotonated in aqueous solution (20 mL) by NaOH (2 mmol, 80 mg), and the resulting solution was mixed slowly with a methanolic solution (20 mL) of 4,4′-bpy (1 mmol, 156 mg) and stirred for 30 min to mix well. Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (1 mmol, 0.308 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of water, and 4 mL of this Cd­(II) solution was slowly and carefully layered with 8 mL of the aforesaid mixed-ligand solution using 4 mL of buffer (1:1 water/MeOH mixture). Colorless block-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained at the wall of the tube after 1 week. The crystals were separated, washed with MeOH, and dried under air. Yield: 82%. Anal. Calcd for C24H26Cd2N4O14 (1) (%): C, 35.18; H, 3.20; N, 6.83. Found (%): C, 34.79; H, 3.31; N, 6.52. IR spectra (KBr pellet, 4000–450 cm–1): 3406 (br), 1608 (s), 1582 (s), 1490 (m), 1404 (s), 1380 (s), 1223 (m), 1067 (m), 1008 (m), 806 (m), 684 (m), 631 (m), 451 (m).

elements.content: Bulk compounds 1–3 were synthesized in powder form by direct mixing of the corresponding ligands and metal salts in a water/methanol mixture at their equimolar ratios. The purity of the compounds was verified by PXRD, which gave a good correspondence between simulated and bulk-phase PXRD patterns, indicating high purity of the bulk compounds. The purity of the bulk samples was further confirmed by the results of elemental analysis and IR spectra as well, which also found in accordance with the data obtained for the single crystals.

The purity of the compounds was verified by PXRD, which gave a good correspondence between simulated and bulk-phase PXRD patterns, indicating high purity of the bulk compounds. The purity of the bulk samples was further confirmed by the results of elemental analysis and IR spectra as well, which also found in accordance with the data obtained for the single crystals.

elements.content: To obtain desolvated frameworks 1′–3′, compounds 1–3 were heated to their corresponding transformation temperatures (obtained from variable-temperature PXRD) under reduced pressure for 4 h. We were unable to obtain single crystals of the transformed products 1′–3′, even when we started with single crystals of 1–3, because of the loss of single-crystallinity upon dehydration.
elements.clean_text: To obtain desolvated frameworks 1'-3', compounds 1-3 were heated to their corresponding transformation temperatures (obtained from variable-temperature PXRD) under reduced pressure for 4 h. We were unable to obtain single crystals of the transformed products 1'-3', even when we started with single crystals of 1-3, because of the loss of single-crystallinity upon dehydration.

elements.content: Single crystals of 1–3 were mounted on thin glass fibers with commercially available glue. Single-crystal X-ray data for all three crystals were collected at room temperature using a Bruker APEX II diffractometer equipped with a normal-focus sealed-tube X-ray source with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated using SAINT, and the absorption corrections were made with SADABS. All three structures were solved by SHELXS-97 using the Patterson method followed by successive Fourier and difference Fourier synthesis. Full matrix least-squares refinements were performed on F 2 using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. During refinement of 3, three lattice water molecules (O3W, O4W, and O5W) were found to be disordered, and their occupancies were fixed at 0.5 before final refinement. In 1 (O5W and O6W) and 2 (O3W, O4W, and O5W), the oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules were isotropically refined without fixing the hydrogen atoms. Potential solvent-accessible area or void space was calculated using PLATON multipurpose crystallographic software. All of the hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically using the HFIX command and placed in ideal positions for all three structures. Calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97, SHELXS-97, PLATON version 1.15, ORTEP-3 version 2, WinGX version 1.80, and TOPOS. Data collection and structure refinement parameters along with crystallographic data for 1–3 are given in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Tables S1, S2, and S5 in the Supporting Information.
elements.clean_text:
Single-Crystal Structure Analysis

Single crystals of 1-3 were mounted on thin glass fibers with commercially available glue. Single-crystal X-ray data for all three crystals were collected at room temperature using a Bruker APEX II diffractometer equipped with a normal-focus sealed-tube X-ray source with graphite monochromatized Mo Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å). The data were integrated using SAINT, and the absorption corrections were made with SADABS. All three structures were solved by SHELXS-97 using the Patterson method followed by successive Fourier and difference Fourier synthesis. Full matrix least-squares refinements were performed on F 2 using SHELXL-97 with anisotropic displacement parameters for all non-hydrogen atoms. During refinement of 3, three lattice water molecules (O3W, O4W, and O5W) were found to be disordered, and their occupancies were fixed at 0.5 before final refinement. In 1 (O5W and O6W) and 2 (O3W, O4W, and O5W), the oxygen atoms of lattice water molecules were isotropically refined without fixing the hydrogen atoms. Potential solvent-accessible area or void space was calculated using PLATON multipurpose crystallographic software. All of the hydrogen atoms were fixed geometrically using the HFIX command and placed in ideal positions for all three structures. Calculations were carried out using SHELXL-97, SHELXS-97, PLATON version 1.15, ORTEP-3 version 2, WinGX version 1.80, and TOPOS. Data collection and structure refinement parameters along with crystallographic data for 1-3 are given in . Selected bond lengths and bond angles are given in Tables S1, S2, and S5 in the Supporting Information.

Low-pressure volumetric N2 gas adsorption studies were carried out with desolvated samples of 1–3 (denoted as 1′–3′) at 77 K (maintained by a liquid nitrogen bath) over the pressure range from 0 to 1 bar using a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ adsorption instrument. CO2 adsorption measurements were also performed at 195 K (dry ice/acetone cold bath) over the same pressure range on the same instrument. High-purity gases (nitrogen, 99.999%; carbon dioxide, 99.95%) were used for the adsorption measurements. The adsorbates were placed into the sample tubes, and then the change in pressure was monitored; the degree of adsorption was determined from the change in pressure to reach the equilibrium state. All of the operations were computer-controlled and automatic. The water adsorption studies on 1′, 2′, and 3′ at 298 K were performed using H2O in the vapor state on the same instrument.
elements.clean_text:
Sorption Measurements

Low-pressure volumetric N2 gas adsorption studies were carried out with desolvated samples of 1-3 (denoted as 1'-3') at 77 K (maintained by a liquid nitrogen bath) over the pressure range from 0 to 1 bar using a Quantachrome Autosorb-iQ adsorption instrument. CO2 adsorption measurements were also performed at 195 K (dry ice/acetone cold bath) over the same pressure range on the same instrument. High-purity gases (nitrogen, 99.999%; carbon dioxide, 99.95%) were used for the adsorption measurements. The adsorbates were placed into the sample tubes, and then the change in pressure was monitored; the degree of adsorption was determined from the change in pressure to reach the equilibrium state. All of the operations were computer-controlled and automatic. The water adsorption studies on 1', 2', and 3' at 298 K were performed using H2O in the vapor state on the same instrument.

elements.content: Compounds 1–3 were synthesized by the slow diffusion technique in a methanol/water medium using 3,4-pyrdc dianion along with the three different N,N′-donor linkers 4,4′-bpy, bpee, and bpp, respectively, and the corresponding metal­(II) solutions [Cd­(II), Mn­(II) and Cu­(II)] at room temperature (). Structure determination of compounds 1–3 revealed that they exhibit different structural topologies because of the different bridging modes of the 3,4-pyrdc ligands, which might have affected the final structural arrangements as well as the sorption properties. In each synthesis, the addition of NaOH as a base was used to neutralize the 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid. The 3,4-pyrdc ligands were completely deprotonated upon coordination to the metal centers, which is evidenced by IR spectra with the absence of the expected absorption band in the range of 1760–1680 cm–1 for the protonated carboxylate groups (Figures S1–S3). The results are well-consistent with the single crystal structures as well. The IR spectra of compounds 1–3 show a broad peak around 3600–3350 cm–1 for O–H stretching, corresponding to the presence of free or coordinated water molecules (Figures S1–S3). The PXRD patterns of 1–3 are in very good correspondence with the simulated patterns for the single crystals, indicating the phase purity of the bulk samples. The purity of the samples was further confirmed by IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Syntheses

Compounds 1-3 were synthesized by the slow diffusion technique in a methanol/water medium using 3,4-pyrdc dianion along with the three different N,N'-donor linkers 4,4'-bpy, bpee, and bpp, respectively, and the corresponding metal(II) solutions [Cd(II), Mn(II) and Cu(II)] at room temperature (). Structure determination of compounds 1-3 revealed that they exhibit different structural topologies because of the different bridging modes of the 3,4-pyrdc ligands, which might have affected the final structural arrangements as well as the sorption properties. In each synthesis, the addition of NaOH as a base was used to neutralize the 3,4-pyridinedicarboxylic acid. The 3,4-pyrdc ligands were completely deprotonated upon coordination to the metal centers, which is evidenced by IR spectra with the absence of the expected absorption band in the range of 1760-1680 cm-1 for the protonated carboxylate groups (Figures S1-S3). The results are well-consistent with the single crystal structures as well. The IR spectra of compounds 1-3 show a broad peak around 3600-3350 cm-1 for O-H stretching, corresponding to the presence of free or coordinated water molecules (Figures S1-S3). The PXRD patterns of 1-3 are in very good correspondence with the simulated patterns for the single crystals, indicating the phase purity of the bulk samples. The purity of the samples was further confirmed by IR spectroscopy and elemental analysis.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 is a 3D porous framework of Cd­(II) ions bridged by 3,4-pyrdc and 4,4′-bipy linkers. It crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 comprises two crystallographically independent Cd­(II) metal centers (heptacoordinated Cd1 and hexacoordinated Cd2), two 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one 4,4′-bipy ligand, and two coordinated water molecules along with four guest water molecules. Each heptacoordinated Cd1 with a CdO5N2 environment is surrounded by two pairs of oxygen atoms (O1, O2 and O7 b , O8 b ) coming from two 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one oxygen from a water molecule (O1W), and two nitrogen atoms, one from a 4,4′-bipy ligand (N3) and one from a 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N2), composing a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry (a). The Cd1–O and Cd1–N distances around Cd1 are in the ranges of 2.297(3)–2.472(3) and 2.318(3)–2.400(3) Å, respectively (Table S1). However, each hexacoordinated Cd2 with a CdO4N2 environment is coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4, O5 a , and O6 a ) from two different 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from another 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N1 b ), and an oxygen from a coordinated water molecule (O2W). The sixth coordination site is occupied by a N atom from a 4,4′-bipy linker (N4) (a). Here the Cd–O and Cd–N bond lengths around Cd2 are in the ranges of 2.225(4)–2.436(3) and 2.305(4)–2.356(3) Å, respectively (Table S1). The bond angles around Cd1 and Cd2 are in the ranges of 53.69(10)–168.07(12) and 53.38(12)–167.68(12)°, respectively (Table S1). Here one 3,4-pyrdc ligand bridges three different Cd­(II) centers through two chelating carboxylate groups and the pyridyl nitrogen atom, whereas the other 3,4-pyrdc ligand also connects three metal centers via a chelating carboxylate group, a monodentate carboxylate group, and the pyridyl nitrogen atom (Figure S4). Thus, two geometrically different Cd­(II) centers connect with each other via two different 3,4-pyrdc ligands to form a wavelike 2D arrangement in the crystallographic ac plane (b). The 4,4′-bipy linkers connect the 2D metal–carboxylate sheets in a criss-cross and canted fashion to create a 3D arrangement (c) with two types of 1D channels (hexagonal and rectangular) along the crystallographic a axis that are occupied by guest water molecules. The dimensions of the hexagonal and rectangular channels are about 5.3 Å × 3.5 Å and 4.7 Å × 2.0 Å, respectively, which provides a void space of ∼29.3% of the total crystal volume. The 3D structure is also stabilized by intermolecular π–π interactions () with centroid–cetroid distances in the range of 4.112–4.434 Å. Network analysis using TOPOS showed that the overall structure consists of (3,4)-connected trinodal nets with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {63}­{65.8} (d).

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 2 is a 3D framework of Mn­(II) ions bridged by 3,4-pyrdc and bpee linkers. Compound 2 crystallizes in the monoclinic space group C2/c. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains one Mn­(II) ion, one 3,4-pyrdc ligand, half of a bpee ligand, and one coordinated water molecule along with half of a guest water molecule. In 2, each Mn­(II) center is hexacoordinated with a MnO4N2 environment coming from three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 a , O3 b , and O4 c ) of three different 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one oxygen from the coordinated water (O1W), one nitrogen atom from a 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N1), and one nitrogen atom from a bpee ligand (N2), forming a distorted octahedral geometry (a). The Mn–O bond lengths are in the range of 2.1057(15)– 2.2147(17) Å, whereas the Mn–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.2913(17)–2.2928(15) Å. The bond angles around the Mn1 center are in the range of 80.54(6)–178.87(6)° (Table S2). Here the coordination mode of 3,4-pyrdc is different from that in the previous structure (Figure S4). Each 3,4-pyrdc connects four different Mn­(II) centers via its pyridyl nitrogen atom as well as monodentate and bidentate carboxylate groups, forming a 2D metal–carboxylate layer (b). Here the bpee ligands connect adjacent metal–carboxylate layers, extending the structural motif into three dimensions, with further support from intermolecular π–π interactions with centroid–cetroid distances in the range of 3.5072–4.2657 Å (Table S3). The formation of the 3D structure is associated with the construction of small cavities along the crystallographic c axis that are occupied by lattice water molecules (c). The effective solvent-accessible void space, calculated using PLATON, was found to be 10.6% of the total crystal volume. Network analysis using TOPOS showed that the overall structure consists of (4,5)-connected binodal nets with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {44.62.104}­{44.62} (d). The coordinated (O1W) and lattice water molecules (O2W) are in short contact with the free carboxylate oxygen atom (O1) of the 3,4-pyrdc ligand through hydrogen bonding, and also, the two water molecules are hydrogen-bonded to each other (Table S4).

elements.content: Compound 3 crystallizes in the orthorhombic crystal system with space group Pna2 1. X-ray structural determination revealed a 2D coordination framework made up of Cu­(II) ions, 3,4-pyrdc ligands, and bpp linkers. The asymmetric unit of 3 contains one Cu­(II) ion, one 3,4-pyrdc ligand, one bpp linker, and two coordinated water molecules along with two and a half lattice water molecules. Each Cu­(II) center is hexacoordinated with a CuO3N3 environment comprising two nitrogen atoms from two different bpp ligands (N1 and N2 a ), one nitrogen atom from one 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N3 b ), one oxygen atom from another 3,4-pyrdc ligand (O1), and two oxygens from the coordinated water molecules (O1W and O2W) and exhibits a distorted octahedral geometry (a). The Cu–O bond lengths are in the range of 1.973(5)–2.746(7) Å, whereas the Cu–N bond lengths are in the range of 2.017(5)–2.018(3) Å. The bond angles around the Cu1 center are in the range of 84.68(14)–175.9(14)° (Table S5). The equatorial Cu–O and Cu–N bond distances are comparable to those in similar reported Cu­(II) structures, while the axial Cu–N and Cu–O bond distances are significantly longer, which is commensurate with the Jahn–Teller-sensitive Cu­(II) ion. Here the 3,4-pyrdc ligand acts as a linear ligand and binds Cu­(II) centers only via the carboxylate group at the 4-position and the pyridyl nitrogen atom, while the carboxylate group at the 3-position is free (Figure S4). Each 3,4-pyrdc bridges two Cu­(II) centers in a monodentate fashion to form a 1D metal–carboxylate chain. These 1D chains are further connected by bpp linkers, leading to the formation of a 2D network along the crystallographic b axis (b). The 2D framework of 3 can be viewed in a simplified way using TOPOS as a 4-connected uninodal net with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {44.62} (c). In the crystal packing, the coordinated water molecules (O1W and O2W) are held together with the uncoordinated carboxylate oxygen atoms (O2 and O4) of the 3,4-pyrdc ligand and the lattice water molecule (O3W) by means of hydrogen bonding along the crystallographic c axis to form a supramolecular 3D structure (d and Table S4). These types of hydrogen bonding probably make the carboxylate oxygen atoms unavailable for coordination to Cu1, prompting the monodentate bridging mode of the 3,4-pyrdc ligands. The dimensions of the channels are about 6.8 Å × 2.6 Å, and upon removal of the lattice water molecules the framework contains void space equal to about 25.35% of the total crystal volume, as suggested by PLATON.

elements.content: To check the thermal stability of the compounds reported in this paper, TGA of 1–3 was carried out. The TGA profile of 1 (Figure S6) indicates a gradual weight loss of 13.5% below 120 °C, which corresponds to the release of the four guest and two coordinated water molecules (calcd 13.18%) in a single step. No further weight loss was observed for this compound up to 240 °C, and after that the framework gradually decomposed. For compound 2, a weight loss of ∼8.3% was observed up to 120 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the one coordinated water and the half of a guest water molecule (calcd 7.98%) per formula unit. After this, it remains without any weight loss up to 270 °C followed by gradual decomposition (Figure S7). The TGA curve for compound 3 shows a gradual weight-loss step of 16.3% at 30–65 °C, corresponding to escape of all of the coordinated and guest water molecules (calcd 15.95%), and after that it gradually decomposes into unidentified products (Figure S8).
elements.clean_text:
Structural Transformation: Thermogravimetric Analysis, Powder X-ray Diffraction, and Morphology Analysis

To check the thermal stability of the compounds reported in this paper, TGA of 1-3 was carried out. The TGA profile of 1 (Figure S6) indicates a gradual weight loss of 13.5% below 120 °C, which corresponds to the release of the four guest and two coordinated water molecules (calcd 13.18%) in a single step. No further weight loss was observed for this compound up to 240 °C, and after that the framework gradually decomposed. For compound 2, a weight loss of ~8.3% was observed up to 120 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the one coordinated water and the half of a guest water molecule (calcd 7.98%) per formula unit. After this, it remains without any weight loss up to 270 °C followed by gradual decomposition (Figure S7). The TGA curve for compound 3 shows a gradual weight-loss step of 16.3% at 30-65 °C, corresponding to escape of all of the coordinated and guest water molecules (calcd 15.95%), and after that it gradually decomposes into unidentified products (Figure S8).

elements.content: The bulk-phase purity of 1–3 was confirmed by comparison of the experimentally observed PXRD patterns with the patterns simulated from the single-crystal structures. The PXRD peaks of the as-synthesized forms matched well with the simulated patterns in all three cases (– ). In view of the thermal stability of the aforesaid compounds, in situ variable-temperature powder X-ray diffraction (VT-PXRD) studies were performed. Samples were placed in the high-temperature cell of the instrument and heated gradually at a rate of 1 °C/s. At the required temperature, data were collected after a delay time of 2 min. VT-PXRD of all three compounds revealed considerable changes in the powder patterns at high temperature (Figures S9–S11), and this could be caused by a phase transformation upon solvent removal. In the case of 1, the diffraction patterns below 70 °C remained almost unchanged, indicating the retention of the crystal lattice. Above 70 °C, the decrease in intensity and slight shifts of some peaks of the PXRD patterns indicate that the framework was partially amorphous after the loss of the lattice and coordinated solvent molecules ( and S9). The VT-PXRD patterns of 2 (Figure S10) reveal that the framework also underwent a crystalline phase transformation starting at 40 °C, where two phases are simultaneously present, and at 50 °C it is exclusively transformed to the desolvated phase. It is also evident from FESEM images (Figures S15 and S16) that 1 and 2 show a crystalline-to-crystalline transformation with similar morphologies but different particle sizes for the hydrated and dehydrated compounds. The VT-PXRD patterns of 3 (Figure S11) show a crystal-to-amorphous transformation upon removal guest molecules, which is also associated with a distinct color change. When heated, 3 started to transform to an amorphous phase above 50 °C, as evidence by the decrease in intensity and slight shifts of some peaks in the PXRD pattern, and finally at 110 °C it was completely transformed to the desolvated phase.

elements.content: The TGA curves of 1′–3′ show single-step weight loss at high temperature (Figures S6–S8), indicating the complete absence of coordinated solvent molecules. When the dehydrated phases of all three compounds were exposed to water vapor environment for 7 days, they returned to their original crystalline phases, indicating the reversible nature of the structural transformations even in the case of 3′, which is basically an unusual amorphous-to-crystal transformation. Nevertheless, we also exposed the dehydrated phases of above-mentioned three compounds (1′–3′) to different polar coordinating solvents (MeOH, EtOH, and THF), but surprisingly, we could not observe any structural change in 1′–3′ upon exposure to these solvents (Figures S12–S14). The above results reveal that the reversible structural changes observed in these compounds are highly selective for water.

When the dehydrated phases of all three compounds were exposed to water vapor environment for 7 days, they returned to their original crystalline phases, indicating the reversible nature of the structural transformations even in the case of 3', which is basically an unusual amorphous-to-crystal transformation. Nevertheless, we also exposed the dehydrated phases of above-mentioned three compounds (1'-3') to different polar coordinating solvents (MeOH, EtOH, and THF), but surprisingly, we could not observe any structural change in 1'-3' upon exposure to these solvents (Figures S12-S14). The above results reveal that the reversible structural changes observed in these compounds are highly selective for water.

elements.content: In order to get the possible insight of the structural changes that happened after the removal of solvent molecules from the frameworks, we also measured IR spectra of the as-synthesized, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of compounds 1–3 (Figures S1–S3). The as-synthesized forms of compounds 1–3 show a broad band at 3406, 3280, and 3385 cm–1, respectively, corresponding to water molecules, and this band almost completely disappears in the dehydrated forms of all three compounds (Figures S1–S3). For the dehydrated forms of all three compounds, the corresponding carboxylate CO (1640–1573 cm–1) and C–O (1412–1573 cm–1) bands become broad, representing changes in the coordination environment around the metal centers ( and S1–S3). Upon exposure to water vapor for 7 days, these broad bands in the dehydrated phases of compounds 1–3 regenerated the original bands present in the parent compounds ( and S1–S3). The UV–vis absorption spectra of the as-synthesized, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of compounds 1–3 were measured in the solid state at room temperature (Figures S17 and S18 and , respectively). The absorption spectra of compounds 1 and 2 were very similar in their different forms (Figures S17 and S18), but compound 3 shows a reversible visible color change corresponding to the hydrated and dehydrated phases (). The as-synthesized compound 3 is blue with an absorption maximum at 623 nm, and the color changes to pale blue upon dehydration (3′) with a shift in the absorption maximum to 700 nm. The color of the desolvated sample changes again from pale blue to the original blue with an absorbance maximum at 623 nm when the desolvated crystals are exposed to water vapor ().
elements.clean_text:
IR and UV Spectra

In order to get the possible insight of the structural changes that happened after the removal of solvent molecules from the frameworks, we also measured IR spectra of the as-synthesized, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of compounds 1-3 (Figures S1-S3). The as-synthesized forms of compounds 1-3 show a broad band at 3406, 3280, and 3385 cm-1, respectively, corresponding to water molecules, and this band almost completely disappears in the dehydrated forms of all three compounds (Figures S1-S3). For the dehydrated forms of all three compounds, the corresponding carboxylate CO (1640-1573 cm-1) and C-O (1412-1573 cm-1) bands become broad, representing changes in the coordination environment around the metal centers ( and S1-S3). Upon exposure to water vapor for 7 days, these broad bands in the dehydrated phases of compounds 1-3 regenerated the original bands present in the parent compounds ( and S1-S3). The UV-vis absorption spectra of the as-synthesized, dehydrated, and rehydrated forms of compounds 1-3 were measured in the solid state at room temperature (Figures S17 and S18 and , respectively). The absorption spectra of compounds 1 and 2 were very similar in their different forms (Figures S17 and S18), but compound 3 shows a reversible visible color change corresponding to the hydrated and dehydrated phases (). The as-synthesized compound 3 is blue with an absorption maximum at 623 nm, and the color changes to pale blue upon dehydration (3') with a shift in the absorption maximum to 700 nm. The color of the desolvated sample changes again from pale blue to the original blue with an absorbance maximum at 623 nm when the desolvated crystals are exposed to water vapor ().

elements.content: Encouraged by the single-crystal X-ray structure and structural flexibility of 1–3, we determined the gas uptake capacities of the desolvated (activated) frameworks. Before the measurements, powder samples of 1–3 were evacuated at 120 °C for 4 h to obtain their activated forms 1′–3′. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated compounds 1′–3′ at 77 K show type-II adsorption profiles with very low uptake, suggesting only surface adsorption (). Surprisingly, even though these compounds are nonporous toward N2, we found that they are porous toward CO2 at 195 K, for which these compounds reveal reversible type-I isotherms. The adsorption isotherms of compounds 1′–3′ with CO2 at 195 K show uptakes of 39 cm3 g–1 (7.7 wt %), 19 cm3 g–1 (3.7 wt %), and 47 cm3 g–1 (9.2 wt %), respectively (). It is interesting to note that the desorption curve does not coincide with the adsorption curve, instead showing a large hysteretic sorption profile. The presence of the huge hysteresis in the adsorption–desorption isotherms indicates that the quadruple moment of CO2 molecules interacts strongly with the framework. The stronger interaction can be attributed to the presence of unsaturated M­(II) sites within the host network and free oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups in desolvated states on the pore walls, which can effectively interact with the CO2 molecules as the carbon atom in CO2 is electron-deficient (Lewis acidic) in nature. This interaction provides extra energy for adsorption, to which the higher uptake of CO2 in the said compounds is attributed (). In comparison to compounds 1′ and 3′, a lower CO2 uptake in the case of 2′ is observed, which is possibly due to the lower solvent-accessible void space.

Adsorption Properties

Encouraged by the single-crystal X-ray structure and structural flexibility of 1-3, we determined the gas uptake capacities of the desolvated (activated) frameworks. Before the measurements, powder samples of 1-3 were evacuated at 120 °C for 4 h to obtain their activated forms 1'-3'. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated compounds 1'-3' at 77 K show type-II adsorption profiles with very low uptake, suggesting only surface adsorption (). Surprisingly, even though these compounds are nonporous toward N2, we found that they are porous toward CO2 at 195 K, for which these compounds reveal reversible type-I isotherms. The adsorption isotherms of compounds 1'-3' with CO2 at 195 K show uptakes of 39 cm3 g-1 (7.7 wt %), 19 cm3 g-1 (3.7 wt %), and 47 cm3 g-1 (9.2 wt %), respectively (). It is interesting to note that the desorption curve does not coincide with the adsorption curve, instead showing a large hysteretic sorption profile. The presence of the huge hysteresis in the adsorption-desorption isotherms indicates that the quadruple moment of CO2 molecules interacts strongly with the framework. The stronger interaction can be attributed to the presence of unsaturated M(II) sites within the host network and free oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups in desolvated states on the pore walls, which can effectively interact with the CO2 molecules as the carbon atom in CO2 is electron-deficient (Lewis acidic) in nature. This interaction provides extra energy for adsorption, to which the higher uptake of CO2 in the said compounds is attributed (). In comparison to compounds 1' and 3', a lower CO2 uptake in the case of 2' is observed, which is possibly due to the lower solvent-accessible void space.

elements.content: To investigate the selectivities of the three compounds 1′, 2′, and 3′ for CO2 over N2, sorption measurements of CO2 and N2 were also performed at ambient temperature (298 K) up to P/P 0 = 1 (Figure S19). For selectivity measurements, the initial slopes of the single-component adsorption isotherms were calculated individually, and the ratios of the initial slopes of the respective isotherms were used to estimate the adsorption selectivities of the three compounds for CO2 over N2. On that basis, the CO2/N2 selectivities were found to be 8.8 for 1′, 3.7 for 2′, and 9.3 for 3′ (Figures S20–S22).
elements.clean_text: To investigate the selectivities of the three compounds 1', 2', and 3' for CO2 over N2, sorption measurements of CO2 and N2 were also performed at ambient temperature (298 K) up to P/P 0 = 1 (Figure S19). For selectivity measurements, the initial slopes of the single-component adsorption isotherms were calculated individually, and the ratios of the initial slopes of the respective isotherms were used to estimate the adsorption selectivities of the three compounds for CO2 over N2. On that basis, the CO2/N2 selectivities were found to be 8.8 for 1', 3.7 for 2', and 9.3 for 3' (Figures S20-S22).

elements.content: To understand the interactions of water molecules with the flexible frameworks, we also performed water vapor adsorption measurements on activated samples of 1′–3′ under ambient conditions (). All three compounds exhibit interesting water sorption profiles. Compound 1′ shows very high H2O uptake (∼37 cm3 g–1) at lower P/P 0 values (0.0–0.05), and the final uptake amount reaches 177.5 mL g–1, which corresponds to 5.6 molecules of H2O per formula unit (). For 2′, the H2O adsorption profile exhibits a nice gate-opening-type profile: almost no uptake occurs at low pressure (P/P 0 ≈ 0.1), but after this a steep rise leads to a final uptake of 121.5 cm3 g–1 (∼3.4 molecules of H2O per formula unit) (). In the case of 3′, up to a relative pressure of P/P 0 ≈ 0.2 there is almost no uptake, and after that there is a gate opening leading to an uptake that reaches 243 cm3 g–1 (∼7.2 molecules of H2O per formula unit) (). The water isotherm of 3′ displays the highest water uptake among the three compounds at P/P 0 ≈ 0.9, whereas in the low pressure region (P/P 0 ≈ 0–0.5) the water uptake of 3′ is lower than those of 1′ and 2′. The low water uptake of 3′ in the low-pressure region illustrates the amorphous nature of the framework along with the orientation of the hydrophobic −CH2 moieties of the bpp ligands toward the pore surface. The sharp uptake after that at higher partial pressures indicates the probable diffusion of H2O molecules in the pore surfaces. Moreover, the strong hysteresis and retention of water molecules even at very low pressure at the end of desorption signifies a strong interaction of water molecules with the unsaturated metal sites on the pore surface, which may also be responsible for the large water uptake by 3′ at higher pressure.

elements.content: By using 3,4-pyrdc and three different N,N′-donor ligands with various divalent transition metal ions, we have constructed three dynamic metal organic frameworks. Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit reversible crystalline-to-crystalline phase transformations upon dehydration and rehydration, whereas compound 3 shows a guest-water-responsive reversible crystal-to-amorphous phase transformation accompanied by a visible color change. The reversible structural transformations of the compounds were monitored and confirmed by IR spectroscopy, FESEM, TGA, and PXRD data. It is also worth mentioning that the dehydrated forms of all three frameworks selectively adsorb CO2 over N2 and that the adsorption study of 3′ reveals the formation of a rare amorphous MOF. Moreover, the water adsorption profiles show stepwise adsorptions in all three cases, which are attributed to their structural transformation on the basis of the very strong coordination affinity of water molecules with the unsaturated metal ions and the hydrogen-bonding affinity of water molecules with the free O atoms of the carboxylate groups in the framework. Therefore, it may be concluded that the close monitoring of the reversible structural transformation in all three cases will enlighten us for the understanding of crystal-to-crystal and crystal-to-amorphous transformations, which are essentially useful for the design of frameworks having the ability to interconvert in the presence of external stimuli. There is no doubt that such smart materials will serve the purpose of sensing and detection in the future along with several other interesting applications.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

By using 3,4-pyrdc and three different N,N'-donor ligands with various divalent transition metal ions, we have constructed three dynamic metal organic frameworks. Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit reversible crystalline-to-crystalline phase transformations upon dehydration and rehydration, whereas compound 3 shows a guest-water-responsive reversible crystal-to-amorphous phase transformation accompanied by a visible color change. The reversible structural transformations of the compounds were monitored and confirmed by IR spectroscopy, FESEM, TGA, and PXRD data. It is also worth mentioning that the dehydrated forms of all three frameworks selectively adsorb CO2 over N2 and that the adsorption study of 3' reveals the formation of a rare amorphous MOF. Moreover, the water adsorption profiles show stepwise adsorptions in all three cases, which are attributed to their structural transformation on the basis of the very strong coordination affinity of water molecules with the unsaturated metal ions and the hydrogen-bonding affinity of water molecules with the free O atoms of the carboxylate groups in the framework. Therefore, it may be concluded that the close monitoring of the reversible structural transformation in all three cases will enlighten us for the understanding of crystal-to-crystal and crystal-to-amorphous transformations, which are essentially useful for the design of frameworks having the ability to interconvert in the presence of external stimuli. There is no doubt that such smart materials will serve the purpose of sensing and detection in the future along with several other interesting applications.

H2-3,4-pyrdc (1 mmol, 168 mg) was deprotonated in aqueous solution (20 mL) by NaOH (2 mmol, 80 mg), and the resulting solution was mixed slowly with a methanolic solution (20 mL) of 4,4′-bpy (1 mmol, 156 mg) and stirred for 30 min to mix well. Cd­(NO3)2·4H2O (1 mmol, 0.308 g) was dissolved in 20 mL of water, and 4 mL of this Cd­(II) solution was slowly and carefully layered with 8 mL of the aforesaid mixed-ligand solution using 4 mL of buffer (1:1 water/MeOH mixture). Colorless block-shaped single crystals suitable for X-ray diffraction analysis were obtained at the wall of the tube after 1 week. The crystals were separated, washed with MeOH, and dried under air. Yield: 82%. Anal. Calcd for C24H26Cd2N4O14 (1) (%): C, 35.18; H, 3.20; N, 6.83. Found (%): C, 34.79; H, 3.31; N, 6.52. IR spectra (KBr pellet, 4000–450 cm–1): 3406 (br), 1608 (s), 1582 (s), 1490 (m), 1404 (s), 1380 (s), 1223 (m), 1067 (m), 1008 (m), 806 (m), 684 (m), 631 (m), 451 (m).

cln_elements.content:
Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 is a 3D porous framework of Cd­(II) ions bridged by 3,4-pyrdc and 4,4′-bipy linkers. It crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 comprises two crystallographically independent Cd­(II) metal centers (heptacoordinated Cd1 and hexacoordinated Cd2), two 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one 4,4′-bipy ligand, and two coordinated water molecules along with four guest water molecules. Each heptacoordinated Cd1 with a CdO5N2 environment is surrounded by two pairs of oxygen atoms (O1, O2 and O7 b , O8 b ) coming from two 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one oxygen from a water molecule (O1W), and two nitrogen atoms, one from a 4,4′-bipy ligand (N3) and one from a 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N2), composing a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry (a). The Cd1–O and Cd1–N distances around Cd1 are in the ranges of 2.297(3)–2.472(3) and 2.318(3)–2.400(3) Å, respectively (Table S1). However, each hexacoordinated Cd2 with a CdO4N2 environment is coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4, O5 a , and O6 a ) from two different 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from another 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N1 b ), and an oxygen from a coordinated water molecule (O2W). The sixth coordination site is occupied by a N atom from a 4,4′-bipy linker (N4) (a). Here the Cd–O and Cd–N bond lengths around Cd2 are in the ranges of 2.225(4)–2.436(3) and 2.305(4)–2.356(3) Å, respectively (Table S1). The bond angles around Cd1 and Cd2 are in the ranges of 53.69(10)–168.07(12) and 53.38(12)–167.68(12)°, respectively (Table S1). Here one 3,4-pyrdc ligand bridges three different Cd­(II) centers through two chelating carboxylate groups and the pyridyl nitrogen atom, whereas the other 3,4-pyrdc ligand also connects three metal centers via a chelating carboxylate group, a monodentate carboxylate group, and the pyridyl nitrogen atom (Figure S4). Thus, two geometrically different Cd­(II) centers connect with each other via two different 3,4-pyrdc ligands to form a wavelike 2D arrangement in the crystallographic ac plane (b). The 4,4′-bipy linkers connect the 2D metal–carboxylate sheets in a criss-cross and canted fashion to create a 3D arrangement (c) with two types of 1D channels (hexagonal and rectangular) along the crystallographic a axis that are occupied by guest water molecules. The dimensions of the hexagonal and rectangular channels are about 5.3 Å × 3.5 Å and 4.7 Å × 2.0 Å, respectively, which provides a void space of ∼29.3% of the total crystal volume. The 3D structure is also stabilized by intermolecular π–π interactions () with centroid–cetroid distances in the range of 4.112–4.434 Å. Network analysis using TOPOS showed that the overall structure consists of (3,4)-connected trinodal nets with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {63}­{65.8} (d).

Structural Transformation: Thermogravimetric Analysis, Powder X-ray Diffraction, and Morphology Analysis

To check the thermal stability of the compounds reported in this paper, TGA of 1–3 was carried out. The TGA profile of 1 (Figure S6) indicates a gradual weight loss of 13.5% below 120 °C, which corresponds to the release of the four guest and two coordinated water molecules (calcd 13.18%) in a single step. No further weight loss was observed for this compound up to 240 °C, and after that the framework gradually decomposed. For compound 2, a weight loss of ∼8.3% was observed up to 120 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the one coordinated water and the half of a guest water molecule (calcd 7.98%) per formula unit. After this, it remains without any weight loss up to 270 °C followed by gradual decomposition (Figure S7). The TGA curve for compound 3 shows a gradual weight-loss step of 16.3% at 30–65 °C, corresponding to escape of all of the coordinated and guest water molecules (calcd 15.95%), and after that it gradually decomposes into unidentified products (Figure S8).

Adsorption Properties

Encouraged by the single-crystal X-ray structure and structural flexibility of 1–3, we determined the gas uptake capacities of the desolvated (activated) frameworks. Before the measurements, powder samples of 1–3 were evacuated at 120 °C for 4 h to obtain their activated forms 1′–3′. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated compounds 1′–3′ at 77 K show type-II adsorption profiles with very low uptake, suggesting only surface adsorption (). Surprisingly, even though these compounds are nonporous toward N2, we found that they are porous toward CO2 at 195 K, for which these compounds reveal reversible type-I isotherms. The adsorption isotherms of compounds 1′–3′ with CO2 at 195 K show uptakes of 39 cm3 g–1 (7.7 wt %), 19 cm3 g–1 (3.7 wt %), and 47 cm3 g–1 (9.2 wt %), respectively (). It is interesting to note that the desorption curve does not coincide with the adsorption curve, instead showing a large hysteretic sorption profile. The presence of the huge hysteresis in the adsorption–desorption isotherms indicates that the quadruple moment of CO2 molecules interacts strongly with the framework. The stronger interaction can be attributed to the presence of unsaturated M­(II) sites within the host network and free oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups in desolvated states on the pore walls, which can effectively interact with the CO2 molecules as the carbon atom in CO2 is electron-deficient (Lewis acidic) in nature. This interaction provides extra energy for adsorption, to which the higher uptake of CO2 in the said compounds is attributed (). In comparison to compounds 1′ and 3′, a lower CO2 uptake in the case of 2′ is observed, which is possibly due to the lower solvent-accessible void space.

To understand the interactions of water molecules with the flexible frameworks, we also performed water vapor adsorption measurements on activated samples of 1′–3′ under ambient conditions (). All three compounds exhibit interesting water sorption profiles. Compound 1′ shows very high H2O uptake (∼37 cm3 g–1) at lower P/P 0 values (0.0–0.05), and the final uptake amount reaches 177.5 mL g–1, which corresponds to 5.6 molecules of H2O per formula unit (). For 2′, the H2O adsorption profile exhibits a nice gate-opening-type profile: almost no uptake occurs at low pressure (P/P 0 ≈ 0.1), but after this a steep rise leads to a final uptake of 121.5 cm3 g–1 (∼3.4 molecules of H2O per formula unit) (). In the case of 3′, up to a relative pressure of P/P 0 ≈ 0.2 there is almost no uptake, and after that there is a gate opening leading to an uptake that reaches 243 cm3 g–1 (∼7.2 molecules of H2O per formula unit) (). The water isotherm of 3′ displays the highest water uptake among the three compounds at P/P 0 ≈ 0.9, whereas in the low pressure region (P/P 0 ≈ 0–0.5) the water uptake of 3′ is lower than those of 1′ and 2′. The low water uptake of 3′ in the low-pressure region illustrates the amorphous nature of the framework along with the orientation of the hydrophobic −CH2 moieties of the bpp ligands toward the pore surface. The sharp uptake after that at higher partial pressures indicates the probable diffusion of H2O molecules in the pore surfaces. Moreover, the strong hysteresis and retention of water molecules even at very low pressure at the end of desorption signifies a strong interaction of water molecules with the unsaturated metal sites on the pore surface, which may also be responsible for the large water uptake by 3′ at higher pressure.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Structural Description of {[Cd2(3,4-pyrdc)2(4,4'-bipy)(H2O)2]⋅4H2O} n  (1)

Single-crystal X-ray analysis revealed that compound 1 is a 3D porous framework of Cd(II) ions bridged by 3,4-pyrdc and 4,4'-bipy linkers. It crystallizes in the monoclinic space group P21/c. The asymmetric unit of 1 comprises two crystallographically independent Cd(II) metal centers (heptacoordinated Cd1 and hexacoordinated Cd2), two 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one 4,4'-bipy ligand, and two coordinated water molecules along with four guest water molecules. Each heptacoordinated Cd1 with a CdO5N2 environment is surrounded by two pairs of oxygen atoms (O1, O2 and O7 b , O8 b ) coming from two 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one oxygen from a water molecule (O1W), and two nitrogen atoms, one from a 4,4'-bipy ligand (N3) and one from a 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N2), composing a distorted pentagonal-bipyramidal geometry (a). The Cd1-O and Cd1-N distances around Cd1 are in the ranges of 2.297(3)-2.472(3) and 2.318(3)-2.400(3) Å, respectively (Table S1). However, each hexacoordinated Cd2 with a CdO4N2 environment is coordinated to three carboxylate oxygen atoms (O4, O5 a , and O6 a ) from two different 3,4-pyrdc ligands, one pyridyl nitrogen atom from another 3,4-pyrdc ligand (N1 b ), and an oxygen from a coordinated water molecule (O2W). The sixth coordination site is occupied by a N atom from a 4,4'-bipy linker (N4) (a). Here the Cd-O and Cd-N bond lengths around Cd2 are in the ranges of 2.225(4)-2.436(3) and 2.305(4)-2.356(3) Å, respectively (Table S1). The bond angles around Cd1 and Cd2 are in the ranges of 53.69(10)-168.07(12) and 53.38(12)-167.68(12)°, respectively (Table S1). Here one 3,4-pyrdc ligand bridges three different Cd(II) centers through two chelating carboxylate groups and the pyridyl nitrogen atom, whereas the other 3,4-pyrdc ligand also connects three metal centers via a chelating carboxylate group, a monodentate carboxylate group, and the pyridyl nitrogen atom (Figure S4). Thus, two geometrically different Cd(II) centers connect with each other via two different 3,4-pyrdc ligands to form a wavelike 2D arrangement in the crystallographic ac plane (b). The 4,4'-bipy linkers connect the 2D metal-carboxylate sheets in a criss-cross and canted fashion to create a 3D arrangement (c) with two types of 1D channels (hexagonal and rectangular) along the crystallographic a axis that are occupied by guest water molecules. The dimensions of the hexagonal and rectangular channels are about 5.3 Å × 3.5 Å and 4.7 Å × 2.0 Å, respectively, which provides a void space of ~29.3% of the total crystal volume. The 3D structure is also stabilized by intermolecular π-π interactions () with centroid-cetroid distances in the range of 4.112-4.434 Å. Network analysis using TOPOS showed that the overall structure consists of (3,4)-connected trinodal nets with the point symbol (Schläfli symbol) {63}{65.8} (d).

Structural Transformation: Thermogravimetric Analysis, Powder X-ray Diffraction, and Morphology Analysis

To check the thermal stability of the compounds reported in this paper, TGA of 1-3 was carried out. The TGA profile of 1 (Figure S6) indicates a gradual weight loss of 13.5% below 120 °C, which corresponds to the release of the four guest and two coordinated water molecules (calcd 13.18%) in a single step. No further weight loss was observed for this compound up to 240 °C, and after that the framework gradually decomposed. For compound 2, a weight loss of ~8.3% was observed up to 120 °C, which can be assigned to the loss of the one coordinated water and the half of a guest water molecule (calcd 7.98%) per formula unit. After this, it remains without any weight loss up to 270 °C followed by gradual decomposition (Figure S7). The TGA curve for compound 3 shows a gradual weight-loss step of 16.3% at 30-65 °C, corresponding to escape of all of the coordinated and guest water molecules (calcd 15.95%), and after that it gradually decomposes into unidentified products (Figure S8).

Adsorption Properties

Encouraged by the single-crystal X-ray structure and structural flexibility of 1-3, we determined the gas uptake capacities of the desolvated (activated) frameworks. Before the measurements, powder samples of 1-3 were evacuated at 120 °C for 4 h to obtain their activated forms 1'-3'. The N2 adsorption isotherms of the activated compounds 1'-3' at 77 K show type-II adsorption profiles with very low uptake, suggesting only surface adsorption (). Surprisingly, even though these compounds are nonporous toward N2, we found that they are porous toward CO2 at 195 K, for which these compounds reveal reversible type-I isotherms. The adsorption isotherms of compounds 1'-3' with CO2 at 195 K show uptakes of 39 cm3 g-1 (7.7 wt %), 19 cm3 g-1 (3.7 wt %), and 47 cm3 g-1 (9.2 wt %), respectively (). It is interesting to note that the desorption curve does not coincide with the adsorption curve, instead showing a large hysteretic sorption profile. The presence of the huge hysteresis in the adsorption-desorption isotherms indicates that the quadruple moment of CO2 molecules interacts strongly with the framework. The stronger interaction can be attributed to the presence of unsaturated M(II) sites within the host network and free oxygen atoms of carboxylate groups in desolvated states on the pore walls, which can effectively interact with the CO2 molecules as the carbon atom in CO2 is electron-deficient (Lewis acidic) in nature. This interaction provides extra energy for adsorption, to which the higher uptake of CO2 in the said compounds is attributed (). In comparison to compounds 1' and 3', a lower CO2 uptake in the case of 2' is observed, which is possibly due to the lower solvent-accessible void space.

To understand the interactions of water molecules with the flexible frameworks, we also performed water vapor adsorption measurements on activated samples of 1'-3' under ambient conditions (). All three compounds exhibit interesting water sorption profiles. Compound 1' shows very high H2O uptake (~37 cm3 g-1) at lower P/P 0 values (0.0-0.05), and the final uptake amount reaches 177.5 mL g-1, which corresponds to 5.6 molecules of H2O per formula unit (). For 2', the H2O adsorption profile exhibits a nice gate-opening-type profile: almost no uptake occurs at low pressure (P/P 0 ~ 0.1), but after this a steep rise leads to a final uptake of 121.5 cm3 g-1 (~3.4 molecules of H2O per formula unit) (). In the case of 3', up to a relative pressure of P/P 0 ~ 0.2 there is almost no uptake, and after that there is a gate opening leading to an uptake that reaches 243 cm3 g-1 (~7.2 molecules of H2O per formula unit) (). The water isotherm of 3' displays the highest water uptake among the three compounds at P/P 0 ~ 0.9, whereas in the low pressure region (P/P 0 ~ 0-0.5) the water uptake of 3' is lower than those of 1' and 2'. The low water uptake of 3' in the low-pressure region illustrates the amorphous nature of the framework along with the orientation of the hydrophobic -CH2 moieties of the bpp ligands toward the pore surface. The sharp uptake after that at higher partial pressures indicates the probable diffusion of H2O molecules in the pore surfaces. Moreover, the strong hysteresis and retention of water molecules even at very low pressure at the end of desorption signifies a strong interaction of water molecules with the unsaturated metal sites on the pore surface, which may also be responsible for the large water uptake by 3' at higher pressure.
